issues.text: Whether the refusal to permit him to import goods on the basis of the said licences violated his fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore filed the present petition in May 1963, and contends that the refusal to permit him to import goods on the basis of the said licences violated his fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19  1   f  and  g  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Government of India allowed import of goods by other merchants who were similarly situate and this amounted to discrimination against him which was violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: He also contends that the Government of India allowed import of goods by other merchants who were similarly situate and this amounted to discrimination against him which was violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether in view of the emergency, Art. 19 has been suspended by virtue of the provisions of Art. 358 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The petition has been opposed on behalf of the Government of India. It is urged that in view of the emergency, Art. 19 has been suspended by virtue of the provisions of Art. 358 of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether the new sovereign, namely, the Government of India recognised these rights with which we are concerned in the present petition after December 20, 1961 when the former Portuguese territories in India were acquired.

anchor.surface_text: It is on the basis of this well-settled position of law that we have to consider whether the new sovereign, namely, the Government of India recognised these rights with which we are concerned in the present petition after December 20, 1961. when the former Portuguese territories in India were acquired.

issues.text: Whether under the Ordinance and the Act, the previous laws were to continue and therefore this amounted to recognition by the Government of India of all rights flowing from the previous laws.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the petitioner is that under the Ordinance and the Act, the previous laws were to continue and therefore this amounted to recognition by the Government of India of all rights flowing from the previous laws and in this connection reliance has been placed on the decision of this Court in Shyamlals case 1 .

issues.text: Whether sub-s. (2) of s. 4 of the Regulation preserved any right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under the repealed law and therefore the right under the licences in favour of the petitioner which were issued under the repealed law were preserved and this amounted to recognition of the petitioner's right under the said licences.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that sub-s.  2  of s. 4 of the Regulation preserved any right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under the repealed law and therefore the right under the licences in favour of the petitioner which were issued under the repealed law were preserved

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has failed to prove discrimination under Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: As to Art. 14, it is enough to say that it was for the petitioner to establish that there was discrimination in his case. He has completely failed to do so,

arguments.claim: Even if valid, licences expired after 180 days; no obligation to extend or allow imports thereafter

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that licences could only be ,ranted by the Governor of Daman at the relevant time and the petitioner has failed to prove that his licence were in fact issued by the Governor of Daman, and therefore the licences are number valid. It is further urged that even if the licences were held to be valid, they were for a period of 180 days.

arguments.claim: Territories acquired by conquest; new sovereign not bound to honour former sovereign's commitments unless recognised

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is urged that the Portuguese territories in India were acquired by conquest as such the new sovereign was not bound as between itself and the subjects of the former Portuguese territories to honour commitments of the former Portuguese Government, and that it was open to the new sovereign either to recognise the commitments of the former Portuguese Government or not to do so. In the present case, the new sovereign, namely, the Government of -India, refused to recognise commitments of the former Portuguese Government of the nature made by the issue of licences to the petitioner and therefore the petitioner is not entitled to any relief from this Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r se when the new sovereign takes over. We are company- cerned only with relations between subjects of the former sovereign and the new sovereign afte

arguments.court_reasoning: Undisputed position of law; applied to facts

arguments.claim: Assume petitioner held valid licences before Dec 20, 1961

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider all the arguments except the one under Art. 14 raised on behalf of the petitioner as we have come to the conclusion that the petitioner is not entitled to any relief in view of the last point urged on behalf of the Government of India. We shall assume for purposes of the present petition that the petitioner did hold valid licences before December 20, 1961 from the former Portuguese Government for import of goods worth over a million pounds.

arguments.claim: In conquest, residents do not carry rights from ex-sovereign; only rights granted/recognised by new sovereign inter se sovereign-subjects

anchor.surface_text: The position of law, however, in cases of acquisition of territories by conquest, as in the present case, is undisputed. In such a case the residents of the territories did not carry with them the rights which they possessed as subjects of the ex-sovereign, and that as subjects of the new sovereign they had only such rights as are granted or recognised by him

arguments.claim: Cites Dalmia Dadri Cement, Vora Fiddali, Shyamlal affirming Act of State doctrine

anchor.surface_text: so far as the relations between the subjects and the sovereign are concerned. In the present case we are not concerned with relations between subject and subject of the former sovereign and their rights inter se when the new sovereign takes over. We are concerned only with relations between subjects of the former sovereign and the new sovereign after the new sovereign has taken over and what we say herein must be confined to that position alone. In M s Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax,  1  this undisputed position of law was laid down by this Court. This position was reiterated by this Court in State of Gujarat v. Vora Fiddali Badruddin Mithibarwala, 2  where it was held that the rule that cession of territory by one State to another is an act of State and the subjects of the former State may enforce only those rights which the new sovereign recognises is well- settled. The same position was again affirmed in Shyamlals case 1

arguments.claim: Dec 30, 1961 proclamation limits recognition to goods at sea with forex paid; petitioner's case not covered

anchor.surface_text: new sovereign, namely, the Government of -India, refused to recognise commitments of the former Portuguese Government of the nature made by the issue of licences to the petitioner and therefore the petitioner is number entitled to any relief from this Court. It is on the basis of this well-settled position of law that we have to consider whether the new sovereign, namely, the Government of India recognised these rights with which we are concerned in the present petition after December 20, 1961 when the former Portuguese territories in India were acquired.

arguments.claim: Jan 11, 1962 letter considers individual cases with pre-Dec 18 commitment; petitioner's case not covered

anchor.surface_text: Further it seems to us clear by implication that every other kind of import except the kind permitted by this proclamation was not recognised. Therefore, as we read this proclamation, it is clear that the new sovereign did not recognise imports on the basis of licences like those granted to the petitioner, unless two conditions were fulfilled, namely,  i  that the goods under the licences were already at sea, and  ii  that the foreign exchange had already been paid with respect to them.

arguments.claim: Ordinance No.11/1961 and Act No.1/1962 continuance of pre-1961 laws does not amount to recognition of all rights/liabilities

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, however, relies on the Goa, Daman and Diu  Administration  Ordinance No. 11 of 1961  promulgated on March 5, 1962. Under s. 4 of the Ordinance, all laws in force before the 20th December 1961 in Goa, Daman and Diu or any part thereof were to continue to be in force therein until amended or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority.

arguments.court_reasoning: Continuance does not imply assumption of sovereign liabilities without explicit provision like covenant in Shyamlal

arguments.claim: Regulation XII/1962 s.4(2) preserves rights under repealed laws hence recognises petitioner's licence rights

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that sub-s.  2  of s. 4 of the Regulation preserved any right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under the repealed law and therefore the right under the licences in favour of the petitioner which were issued under the repealed law were preserved

court_response_anchor.surface_text: after the appointed day and before the companymencement of this Ordinance, by the Administrator or any other officer of Government, whether civil or

arguments.court_reasoning: Licences predate enforcement of Regulation; repealed laws in force only from Mar 5, 1962

arguments.claim: Shyamlal supports recognition via continuance of old laws

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the petitioner is that under the Ordinance and the Act, the previous laws were to continue and therefore this amounted to recognition by the Government of India of all rights flowing from the previous laws and in this connection reliance has been placed on the decision of this Court in Shyamlals case 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ate had recognised the liabilities of the old State was number based only on the fact that the old laws were companytinued it was fortified by the fur

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: Shyamlal fortified by covenant Art.VI assuming liabilities; no such provision here; proclamation contradicts

arguments.claim: Apr 2, 1962 order and Apr 11, 1962 order do not cover petitioner's case; no recognition

anchor.surface_text: Our attention is also drawn to certain other orders passed after March 5, 1962 in connection with imports. One such order was passed on April 2, 1962 which stated that imports into Goa, Daman and Diu from abroad will be governed by the following principles... It is however admitted on behalf of the petitioner that his case is not covered by even this order of April 2, 1962... Then on April 11, 1962, another order was issued... Thus there was never any recognition of the right of the petitioner under the licences, which he held,

arguments.claim: Petitioner failed to prove discrimination under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: As to Art. 14, it is enough to say that it was for the petitioner to establish that there was discrimination in his case. He has completely failed to do so,

holdings.text: The petitioner is not entitled to any relief because the new sovereign did not recognise the rights arising out of the licences in question.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider all the arguments except the one under Art. 14 raised on behalf of the petitioner as we have come to the conclusion that the petitioner is not entitled to any relief in view of the last point urged on behalf of the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New sovereign acquires territory by conquest; rights of former subjects enforceable only if explicitly recognised by new sovereign; no such recognition here via proclamations, ordinances, acts, or regulations.

holdings.text: In cases of acquisition of territories by conquest, residents do not carry rights possessed as subjects of ex-sovereign; only such rights as granted or recognised by new sovereign inter se sovereign and subjects.

anchor.surface_text: The position of law, however, in cases of acquisition of territories by conquest, as in the present case, is undisputed. In such a case the residents of the territories did not carry with them the rights which they possessed as subjects of the ex-sovereign, and that as subjects of the new sovereign they had only such rights as are granted or recognised by him

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed law affirmed by Supreme Court precedents: Dalmia Dadri Cement, Vora Fiddali, Shyamlal.

holdings.text: Military Governor's proclamation of December 30, 1961 did not recognise imports on basis of petitioner's licences as goods not at sea with foreign exchange paid.

anchor.surface_text: new sovereign, namely, the Government of -India, refused to recognise commitments of the former Portuguese Government of the nature made by the issue of licences to the petitioner and therefore the petitioner is not entitled to any relief from this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proclamation textually limits recognition to exports by sea per prior law and imports already at sea with forex paid; petitioner's case lacks these conditions.

holdings.text: Continuance of pre-1961 laws under Ordinance No.11/1961 and Act No.1/1962 does not amount to recognition by new sovereign of liabilities of former sovereign.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 4 of the Ordinance, all laws in force before the 20th December 1961 in Goa, Daman and Diu or any part thereof were to continue to be in force therein until amended or repealed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Shyamlal (covenant explicitly assumed liabilities); no equivalent provision here; contradicted by Dec 30 proclamation limiting recognition.

holdings.text: As between subjects and new sovereign, old laws did not continue during interregnum Dec 20, 1961 to Mar 5, 1962; actions validated by ss.7 Ordinance/9 Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there was never any recognition of the right of the petitioner under the licences, which he held,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validation provisions imply old laws not automatically continued inter sovereign-subjects; proclamation lawful per validation.

holdings.text: Petitioner's licences not covered by April 2/11, 1962 orders requiring valid import licences; no recognition.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention is also drawn to certain other orders passed after March 5, 1962 in connection with imports. One such order was passed on April 2, 1962 which stated that imports into Goa, Daman and Diu from abroad

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner admits not covered; orders impose new requirements post-Mar 5.

holdings.text: Regulation No.XII/1962 s.4(2) does not preserve rights under pre-Mar 5, 1962 licences against new sovereign.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention is also drawn to certain other orders passed after March 5, 1962 in connection with imports. One such order was passed on April 2, 1962 which stated that imports into Goa, Daman and Diu from abroad

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repealed laws in force only from Mar 5; licences predate acquisition/continuance.

holdings.text: Petitioner completely failed to establish discrimination under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: As to Art. 14, it is enough to say that it was for the petitioner to establish that there was discrimination in his case. He has completely failed to do so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reliable evidence beyond vague assertions that others similarly situated permitted imports.

anchor.surface_text: State of Rajasthan v. Shyamlal.  1  The petition has been opposed on behalf of the Government of India.

precedents.cited_proposition: Government of India bound to honour import licences granted by former Portuguese Government as it recognised the right to import under the licences

precedents.citation: M s Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax,  1
